Business

• A class-action lawsuit against Sterling Jewelers that accuses the company of pay discrimination against women has shed light on the drawbacks of widely used corporate procedures like confidential tip lines.

And in Britain, lawmakers are pressing for stronger rules to ensure that women will never again be forced to wear high heels at work.

• Many people whose jobs have been automated can’t find new ones. We look at policies economists think could help.

• The user agreement that iTunes customers are asked to sign is the basis of a new graphic novel, “Terms and Conditions.”

• U.S. stocks were down on Monday. Here’s a snapshot of global markets.

Smarter Living

• Should supplements be a part of your morning routine? The science is still mostly unclear.

• Recipe of the day: Elegant mini almond cakes can be filled with cherry jam or, with a little effort, chocolate ganache.

Noteworthy

• A tour of the “Batcave.”

Video

A derelict warehouse in Brooklyn was a haven for graffiti artists for decades. Our 360 video visits the space before it gets renovated.

• It’s mating season in the Galápagos.

The booby has no real predators to fear in the Ecuadorean archipelago.

Photo

As a result, the blue-footed bird lives a proud and public life, on display in its highly ritualized courtship.

• Risky entertainment.

“Afghan Star,” a TV competition similar to “American Idol,” serves as a counterweight in a conservative society that mostly views music as vulgar, especially when the performers are women.

The show’s judges drive around in armored vehicles, and the contestants live in a compound in Kabul for the duration of the program.

• Best of late-night TV.

Anderson Cooper of CNN stopped by “The Late Show” to talk about President Trump’s posts on Twitter.

Back Story

The U.S. Postal Service’s stamp issue this week pays homage to the federal arts program that gave some of the 20th century’s most famous American artists their start.

Advertisement Continue reading the main story

But it might not have.

Photo

In the mid-1930s, at the height of the Depression, unemployment was soaring at 25 percent. President Franklin D. Roosevelt created the Work Projects Administration to put Americans back to work.

Artists, who often didn’t have regular jobs in the first place, weren’t certain to be included. But Harry Hopkins, who directed the W.P.A., decided they should be.

“Hell,” he said, “they’ve got to eat just like other people!”

So the Federal Art Project of the W.P.A. was created. Over nine years, it spawned more than 100,000 paintings and murals and nearly 20,000 sculptures.

Some of the artists employed by the program went on to become famous, including Jackson Pollock, Mark Rothko, and Willem de Kooning.

“I changed my attitude toward being an artist,” de Kooning once said. “Instead of doing odd jobs and painting on the side, I painted and did odd jobs on the side.”

Evan Gershkovich contributed reporting.
